hints_html:
Because the expression is a function for x and is to be rotated about the x-axis, we should use the disc method. When using the disc method, we want to evaluate the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \pi \int_a^b [f(x)^2 - g(x)^2] dx\end{aligned}\]

where a and b are the smallest and largest values of x in the region, f(x) is the largest y-value in the region at x (which will be the outer radius of the disc) , and g(x) is the smallest y-value in the region at x (which will be the inner radius of the disc).

For this region, we have that \(a = 0\). The rightmost x-value \(b\) is the point of intersection of the circle \(x^2 + y^2 = 1\) and the line \(y = x\). Try to find the value of b and evaluate the integral.

For this region, we have that $a = 0$. The rightmost x-value $b$ is the
point of intersection of the circle $x^2 + y^2 = 1$ and the line
$y = x$. Try to find the value of b and evaluate the integral.
hints_raw:
Because the expression is a function for x and is to be rotated about the x-axis, we should use the disc method.  When using the disc method, we want to evaluate the integral
:<math> \pi \int_a^b [f(x)^2 - g(x)^2] dx </math>
where a and b are the smallest and largest values of x in the region, f(x) is the largest y-value in the region at x (which will be the outer radius of the disc) , and g(x) is the smallest y-value in the region at x (which will be the inner radius of the disc).  

For this region, we have that <math> a = 0 </math>.  The rightmost x-value <math> b </math> is the point of intersection of the circle <math> x^2 + y^2 = 1 </math> and the line <math> y = x </math>.  Try to find the value of b and evaluate the integral.
question: 3 (a)
sols_html:
The equation of a circle with radius 1 is x2+y2=1 or, once we solve for \(y\), \(y=\sqrt{1-x^2}\) (which gives the upper half of the circle). Because we are rotating around the x-axis, we will be integrating between two points on the x-axis. The left endpoint is clearly 0. The right endpoint is a little trickier: it will be the point where \(y = x\) and \(y = \sqrt{1 - x^2}\) intersect. This point of intersection is found by setting these two curves equal and solving:

\[\begin{aligned} x &= \sqrt{1-x^2} \\ x^2 &= 1 - x^2 \\ x^2 &= \frac12 \\ x &= \pm\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\end{aligned}\]

.

Because we are in the first quadrant, the intersection point must be positive. Thus we will be integrating between \(\displaystyle 0\) and \(\frac1{\sqrt{2}}.\)

If we use the Disc Method, the outside radius of the disc will be the arc of the circle, given by \(y = \sqrt{1-x^2}\) and the inside radius will be given by the line \(y = x\). Plugging these, and our endpoints, into the integral, we get:

\[\begin{aligned} V &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi \left[\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)^2 - \left(x\right)^2\right] dx \\ &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi \left[1-2x^2\right] dx \\ &= \pi \left[ x-\frac{2x^3}{3}\right]_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \\ &= \pi \left[ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{3\sqrt{2}}\right] \\ &= \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}\pi\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
The equation of a circle with radius 1 is
\emph{x}\textsuperscript{2}+\emph{y}\textsuperscript{2}=1 or, once we
solve for $y$, $y=\sqrt{1-x^2}$ (which gives the upper half of the
circle). Because we are rotating around the \emph{x}-axis, we will be
integrating between two points on the \emph{x}-axis. The left endpoint
is clearly \emph{0}. The right endpoint is a little trickier: it will be
the point where $y = x$ and $y = \sqrt{1 - x^2}$ intersect. This point
of intersection is found by setting these two curves equal and solving:

\begin{align*}
x &= \sqrt{1-x^2} \\ x^2 &= 1 - x^2  \\ x^2 &= \frac12 \\ x &= \pm\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}
\end{align*}.

Because we are in the first quadrant, the intersection point must be
positive. Thus we will be integrating between $\displaystyle 0$ and
$\frac1{\sqrt{2}}.$

If we use the Disc Method, the outside radius of the disc will be the
arc of the circle, given by $y = \sqrt{1-x^2}$ and the inside radius
will be given by the line $y = x$. Plugging these, and our endpoints,
into the integral, we get:

\begin{align*}
V &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi \left[\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)^2 - \left(x\right)^2\right] dx \\
&= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi \left[1-2x^2\right] dx  \\
&= \pi \left[ x-\frac{2x^3}{3}\right]_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}  \\
&= \pi \left[ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{3\sqrt{2}}\right] \\
&= \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}\pi
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
The equation of a circle with radius 1 is ''x''<sup>2</sup>+''y''<sup>2</sup>=1 or, once we solve for <math>y</math>,  <math> y=\sqrt{1-x^2}</math> (which gives the upper half of the circle).  Because we are rotating around the ''x''-axis, we will be integrating between two points on the ''x''-axis.  The left endpoint is clearly ''0''.  The right endpoint is a little trickier: it will be the point where <math>y = x</math> and <math>y = \sqrt{1 - x^2}</math> intersect.  This point of intersection is found by setting these two curves equal and solving: 

:<math> 
\begin{align}
x &= \sqrt{1-x^2} \\ x^2 &= 1 - x^2  \\ x^2 &= \frac12 \\ x &= \pm\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\end{align}</math>.  

Because we are in the first quadrant, the intersection point must be positive.   Thus we will be integrating between <math> \displaystyle 0 </math> and <math>\frac1{\sqrt{2}}.</math>

If we use the Disc Method, the outside radius of the disc will be the arc of the circle, given by <math>y = \sqrt{1-x^2}</math> and the inside radius will be given by the line <math> y = x</math>.  Plugging these, and our endpoints, into the integral, we get: 

:<math>
\begin{align}
V &= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi \left[\left(\sqrt{1-x^2}\right)^2 - \left(x\right)^2\right] dx \\
&= \int_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}} \pi \left[1-2x^2\right] dx  \\
&= \pi \left[ x-\frac{2x^3}{3}\right]_0^{\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}}  \\
&= \pi \left[ \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-\frac{1}{3\sqrt{2}}\right] \\
&= \frac{\sqrt{2}}{3}\pi
\end{align}
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the area A between a circle of radius 1 in the first quadrant and \(f(x)\)=x.

Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating A about the x-axis.
statement_raw:
Consider the area ''A'' between a circle of radius 1 in the first quadrant and &fnof;(''x'')=''x''.

:[[File:Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH103_April_2012_Question_3_(a)_Fig.jpg|250px]]

Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating ''A'' about the ''x''-axis.
